speaker: Alice
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

speaker: Neil
text: … and I'm Neil.

speaker: Alice
text: So Neil, did you sleep well last night?

speaker: Neil
text: Um, yes, thanks. Why do you ask?

speaker: Alice
text: Today we're talking about how much sleep we need.

speaker: Neil
text: I like a good eight hours myself – ten at the weekend. How about you?

speaker: Alice
text: Six is enough for me. But did you know this? Humans sleep around three hours less than other primates like chimps, who sleep for about ten hours. So you're a chimp, Neil – at the weekends, at least! Are you ready for the quiz question?

speaker: Neil
text: [makes some chimp noises]

speaker: Alice
text: OK, I'll assume that means yes. Right. What's another word for sleepwalking? Is it…

speaker: Alice
text: a) narcolepsy?

speaker: Alice
text: b) restless legs syndrome?

speaker: Alice
text: or c) somnambulism?

speaker: Neil
text: I will go for b) restless legs syndrome, since there's a connection there with the legs.

speaker: Alice
text: Well we'll find out whether you're right or wrong later on in the show. So what keeps you awake at night, Neil?

speaker: sleep like a logSnoring
text: Not much, to be honest. I usually sleep like a log – and that means very heavily indeed! But sometimes my own snoring wakes me up, and then I can find it hard to get back to sleep. Snoring, for those of you who don't know, means breathing in a noisy way through your mouth or nose while you're asleep. [snores] … like that… How about you, Alice?

speaker: caffeine
text: Very good, yes. Well, that's quite ridiculous! Anyway, for me, it's drinking too much coffee during the day. It's the caffeine in coffee – a chemical that makes you feel more awake – which can stop you from sleeping at night. But there are so many things that can keep us awake these days.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes. Radio, TV… techy stuff like 24-hour internet, computers, smart phones. I love my phone and it's never far from me!

speaker: Alice
text: Well, let's hear what Professor Jerome Siegel, from the University of California, found when he studied the sleep habits of three different hunter-gatherer communities who have very little contact with modern society. They don't have artificial light, electricity, batteries, or any of the gadgets that we rely on today.

speaker: Professor Jerome Siegel, from the University of California, US
text: Their sleep was not that different from ours. The range of sleep period was about 6.9 to 8.5 hours. If you actually measure sleep in current populations in the United States or in Europe they're definitely at the low end of what's been reported. They certainly don't sleep a lot less than we do but they clearly don't sleep more.

speaker: insomnia
text: Professor Jerome Siegel found that people in these communities don't go to bed until several hours after sundown – just like us! But one big difference is that very few of them suffer from insomnia – which means having difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep.

speaker: hunter-gatherers
text: Now, I don't have a problem with insomnia. And hunter-gatherers – people who live by hunting animals and gathering plants to eat – don't either – probably because they take a lot of physical exercise during the day.

speaker: soundly
text: Yes, that's right. Taking exercise is an important factor in sleeping soundly – or well – at night. But these days our minds can be so active that it becomes very difficult to fall asleep. Let's listen to Professor Kevin Morgan, from Loughborough University here in England, talking about how cognitive behavioural therapy can be used to help people with insomnia.

speaker: Professor Kevin Morgan, Loughborough University, England
text: If you have a train of thoughts which would otherwise keep you awake one way of dealing with this is to block those thoughts. What I'd like you to do is repeat the word 'the' in your mind at irregular intervals – the the the the the the the the the – what you'll find (is) that the mind space required to do this blocks out almost everything else.

speaker: irregular
text: So Professor Kevin Morgan suggests saying one word over and over again at irregular intervals – irregular in this context means not spaced out evenly. Doing it can help to block out the thoughts that are stopping you from getting to sleep. It sounds like a very simple solution. I wonder if it works?

speaker: Alice
text: There's one way to find out, Neil. Try it yourself!

speaker: Neil
text: I will.

speaker: cognitive behavioural therapy
text: OK. And cognitive behavioural therapy by the way is a treatment for mental health problems that tries to change the way you think.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I usually count sheep if I can't get to sleep. Do you do that, Alice?

speaker: Alice
text: No, not usually. No. OK, I think it's time for the answer to our quiz question. I asked: What's another word for sleepwalking? Is it… a) narcolepsy? b) restless legs syndrome? or c) somnambulism?

speaker: Neil
text: And I said b) restless legs syndrome.

speaker: Alice
text: Sorry, Neil, it's actually c) somnambulism – the roots of this word come from Latin. Somnus means 'sleep' and and ambulare means 'walk'. Narcolepsy is a condition where you can't stop yourself falling asleep, especially during the day.

speaker: Neil
text: Narcolepsy… (says in a sleepy way)

speaker: Alice
text: And restless legs syndrome is a condition that makes you desperate to move your legs around, especially when you're sitting quietly or trying to get to sleep.

speaker: Neil
text: … get to sleep… (murmuring)

speaker: Alice
text: Neil! Wake up!

speaker: Neil
text: Oh, hello Alice! Sorry.

speaker: Alice
text: Hello! Can we hear today's words again, please?
